questions.question: What is digital marketing?
options: Using digital channels (internet, mobile, social media) to promote products and reach customers
questions.explanation: Digital marketing is promoting products, services, or brands using digital channels and technologies, primarily the internet and electronic devices. Main channels: (1) Search engines (SEO, SEM/PPC), (2) Social media (Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, Twitter, TikTok), (3) Email marketing, (4) Content marketing (blogs, videos, podcasts), (5) Display advertising (banner ads), (6) Affiliate marketing, (7) Influencer marketing, (8) Mobile marketing (apps, SMS). Advantages vs. traditional marketing: (1) Measurable: track metrics precisely (ROI, conversions, engagement), (2) Targeted: reach specific demographics/interests, (3) Cost-effective: lower entry costs, scalable, (4) Interactive: two-way communication with customers, (5) Global reach: transcend geographic boundaries, (6) Real-time optimization: adjust campaigns based on performance. Core activities: market research, strategy development, campaign creation, execution, analysis, optimization. Data-driven approach using analytics tools (Google Analytics, social insights) to refine tactics.

questions.question: What is a marketing funnel?
options: A tool for pouring marketing materials
The customer journey from awareness to purchase, visualized as stages narrowing toward conversion
questions.explanation: A marketing funnel visualizes the customer journey from first awareness to final purchase, shaped like a funnel because fewer people progress through each stage. Common models: (1) AIDA: Awareness (discover brand), Interest (engage with content), Desire (want product), Action (purchase), (2) TOFU-MOFU-BOFU: Top of Funnel (awareness, broad audience, educational content), Middle (consideration, nurturing leads, comparison content), Bottom (decision, ready to buy, product demos, testimonials). Full funnel: Awareness → Interest → Consideration → Intent → Evaluation → Purchase → Loyalty → Advocacy. Metrics by stage: Awareness (impressions, reach, traffic), Consideration (engagement, time on site, leads), Conversion (sales, conversion rate, revenue). Strategies: (1) Top: content marketing, SEO, social media, (2) Middle: email nurturing, retargeting, webinars, (3) Bottom: demos, consultations, special offers. Post-purchase: retention, upselling, referrals. Funnel analysis identifies drop-off points for optimization.

questions.question: What is the difference between organic and paid social media marketing?
options: Organic uses free, unpaid posts building community; paid uses advertisements targeting specific audiences
questions.explanation: Organic vs. paid social media differ in cost, reach, and strategy. Organic social: free posts on business profiles, building community naturally. Characteristics: (1) Cost: free to post (time investment), (2) Reach: limited by algorithm (typically 5-10% of followers), declining over time, (3) Growth: slower but sustainable, (4) Content: engaging posts, stories, interactions, community building, (5) Goals: brand awareness, loyalty, customer service, trust. Best for: long-term relationships, brand personality, customer engagement. Paid social: advertisements targeted at specific audiences. Characteristics: (1) Cost: pay per click (CPC), impression (CPM), or action, (2) Reach: broad, precise targeting (demographics, interests, behaviors, lookalike audiences), (3) Growth: fast, scalable with budget, (4) Content: ad creatives, compelling CTAs, conversion-focused, (5) Goals: lead generation, sales, website traffic, app installs. Best for: product launches, promotions, rapid growth. Strategy: integrate both - organic builds community, paid amplifies reach and drives conversions. Platforms: Facebook Ads, Instagram Ads, LinkedIn Ads, Twitter Ads.

questions.question: What is email marketing and why is it effective?
options: Sending targeted messages to subscribers' inboxes to nurture leads and drive conversions with high ROI
questions.explanation: Email marketing sends commercial messages to a list of subscribers who opted in to receive communications, one of the most effective digital marketing channels. Why effective: (1) High ROI: $36-42 return per $1 spent (highest of any channel), (2) Direct access: reach customers in their inbox, (3) Personalization: segment by behavior, preferences, demographics, (4) Ownership: you own the list (unlike social media), (5) Automation: triggered campaigns based on actions, (6) Measurable: track opens, clicks, conversions. Types: (1) Promotional: sales, offers, new products, (2) Newsletters: regular updates, content, (3) Transactional: order confirmations, receipts, (4) Behavioral: triggered by actions (cart abandonment, browse history), (5) Drip campaigns: automated series nurturing leads. Best practices: permission-based, compelling subject lines, mobile-responsive, clear CTAs, A/B testing, segmentation, avoid spam triggers. Tools: Mailchimp, Constant Contact, SendGrid, ConvertKit. Key metrics: open rate (15-25% average), click-through rate (2-5%), conversion rate, unsubscribe rate.

questions.question: What is content marketing?
options: Creating and distributing valuable, relevant content to attract and retain a clearly defined audience
questions.explanation: Content marketing creates and shares valuable, relevant, consistent content to attract and retain a target audience, ultimately driving profitable customer action. Focus: providing value, not explicitly promoting products. Types: (1) Blog posts: SEO traffic, thought leadership, education, (2) Videos: YouTube, social media, high engagement, (3) Infographics: visual data, shareable, (4) Podcasts: audio content, convenience, (5) Ebooks/whitepapers: in-depth guides, lead magnets, (6) Case studies: proof, credibility, (7) Social media content: bite-sized, engaging, (8) Webinars: interactive education. Benefits: (1) Builds trust and authority, (2) Improves SEO (quality content ranks), (3) Generates leads (gated content), (4) Nurtures prospects through funnel, (5) Cost-effective long-term strategy, (6) Supports other channels (email, social). Strategy: (1) Identify audience personas, (2) Define goals (awareness, leads, sales), (3) Create valuable content addressing pain points, (4) Distribute across channels, (5) Measure performance, (6) Optimize. Content marketing is about storytelling, education, and value - not selling directly.

questions.question: What is PPC (Pay-Per-Click) advertising?
options: An advertising model where advertisers pay a fee each time their ad is clicked, buying visits to their site
questions.explanation: PPC (Pay-Per-Click) is an online advertising model where advertisers pay a fee each time someone clicks their ad, essentially buying visits rather than earning them organically. How it works: (1) Advertisers bid on keywords, (2) Ads appear in search results or on websites, (3) Pay only when clicked (not impressions), (4) Cost determined by competition and Quality Score. Main platforms: (1) Google Ads: search ads (above/below organic results), display network (banner ads), shopping ads, YouTube ads, (2) Microsoft Advertising (Bing), (3) Social media: Facebook Ads, LinkedIn Ads, Twitter Ads. Key concepts: (1) CPC (Cost Per Click): amount paid per click, (2) CTR (Click-Through Rate): clicks / impressions, (3) Quality Score: Google's rating (1-10) based on ad relevance, landing page, CTR, (4) Ad Rank: determines position = bid × Quality Score. Benefits: immediate traffic, precise targeting, measurable ROI, budget control, A/B testing capability. Campaign structure: campaign → ad groups → keywords/ads. Optimization: refine keywords, improve ad copy, optimize landing pages, adjust bids, negative keywords.

questions.question: What is A/B testing in digital marketing?
options: Comparing two versions of a webpage or ad element to determine which performs better statistically
questions.explanation: A/B testing (split testing) compares two versions of a webpage, email, ad, or other marketing asset to determine which performs better based on a specific metric. How it works: (1) Create two versions differing in one element (headline, CTA, image, color, layout), (2) Split traffic randomly (50/50), (3) Measure performance (conversions, clicks, engagement), (4) Analyze results for statistical significance, (5) Implement winning version. What to test: (1) Headlines/copy, (2) CTA buttons (text, color, size, placement), (3) Images/videos, (4) Page layout, (5) Email subject lines, (6) Form fields (length, types), (7) Pricing displays, (8) Navigation. Metrics: conversion rate, click-through rate, bounce rate, time on page, revenue. Best practices: (1) Test one variable at a time (isolate impact), (2) Sufficient sample size (statistical significance), (3) Run long enough (account for variability), (4) Document results, (5) Continuous testing (optimization never ends). Tools: Google Optimize, Optimizely, VWO, Unbounce. Data-driven decision making over guesswork - small changes can yield significant improvements.

questions.question: What is retargeting (remarketing)?
options: Showing ads to people who previously visited your website or engaged with your brand but didn't convert
questions.explanation: Retargeting (remarketing) displays ads to users who previously interacted with your website or brand but didn't convert, keeping your brand top-of-mind and encouraging return visits. How it works: (1) User visits your website, (2) Browser cookie/pixel tracks them, (3) They leave without converting, (4) Ads follow them across the web (Google Display Network, social media, other sites), (5) Ads encourage return and conversion. Types: (1) Site retargeting: visited website, (2) Search retargeting: searched keywords, (3) Social media retargeting: engaged with social content (Facebook Pixel, LinkedIn Insight Tag), (4) Email retargeting: opened emails, (5) Dynamic retargeting: show specific products viewed. Why effective: (1) Higher conversion rates (visitors need 5-7 impressions), (2) Brand recall, (3) Personalized messaging, (4) Cost-effective (targeting warm leads). Strategies: segment audiences (cart abandoners, product viewers, blog readers), sequential messaging (different ads over time), frequency caps (avoid ad fatigue), exclusions (recent purchasers). Platforms: Google Ads, Facebook Ads, AdRoll, Criteo. Critical for e-commerce (average 98% visitors don't convert first visit).

questions.question: What are key performance indicators (KPIs) in digital marketing?
options: Measurable metrics evaluating success of marketing campaigns against business objectives
questions.explanation: KPIs (Key Performance Indicators) are measurable metrics evaluating how effectively marketing campaigns achieve business objectives, providing data-driven insights for optimization. Common KPIs by goal: (1) Awareness: impressions, reach, brand mentions, website traffic, social followers, (2) Engagement: CTR (click-through rate), bounce rate, time on site, pages per session, social engagement (likes, shares, comments), (3) Lead generation: conversion rate, cost per lead (CPL), lead quality score, form submissions, (4) Sales: ROI (return on investment), ROAS (return on ad spend), revenue, cost per acquisition (CPA), average order value (AOV), (5) Retention: customer lifetime value (CLV/LTV), churn rate, repeat purchase rate, net promoter score (NPS). Calculations: Conversion rate = (conversions / total visitors) × 100, ROI = (revenue - cost) / cost × 100, CPA = total ad spend / conversions. Best practices: align KPIs with business goals, track consistently, benchmark against industry averages, focus on actionable metrics (not vanity metrics), use dashboards (Google Analytics, Data Studio). Data-driven decision making essential for marketing success.

questions.question: What is influencer marketing?
options: Partnering with individuals who have engaged followings to promote products to their audience authentically
questions.explanation: Influencer marketing partners with individuals who have established credibility and engaged followings on social media to promote products/services to their audience authentically. How it works: (1) Identify relevant influencers (aligned with brand values, target audience), (2) Negotiate partnership (sponsored posts, affiliate, ambassador), (3) Influencer creates authentic content featuring product, (4) Content reaches and influences their followers, (5) Track performance (engagement, conversions, ROI). Influencer tiers: (1) Nano: 1K-10K followers (high engagement, niche), (2) Micro: 10K-100K (engaged communities, affordable, authentic), (3) Macro: 100K-1M (wider reach, professional content), (4) Mega: 1M+ (celebrities, massive reach, expensive). Benefits: (1) Trust and credibility (recommendations from trusted sources), (2) Targeted reach (specific demographics/niches), (3) Authentic content (less ad-like), (4) SEO and brand awareness. Platforms: Instagram (most popular), YouTube, TikTok, blogs. Compensation: flat fee, commission (affiliate), free products, combination. Success metrics: engagement rate, reach, conversions, ROI. Disclosure: legally required (FTC guidelines - #ad, #sponsored).
